ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2 meetings during the semester 2 hrs each.
0 seminar class
0 hours
None
This seminar was one section. I did not spend any time outside of this seminar.
A few.
0 hours per week
less than 1
none
0 hours
0 hours outside of the classroom.
2 day seminar
N/A
none
It was a two day ethics seminar. No outside work
1 hour
none, it was a two night seminar
this was a two part seminar

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good.
The instructor made the course interesting
interesting
This course was exactly what it needed to be. It was concise and provided us with the necessary information that we need to know the limitations and boundaries of research ethics.
It was annoying that we had to attend this course for two nights, but it was not nearly as bad as it could have been.
Dr. Bruce did a very nice job
Good introduction into ethics - an important topic everyone should be aware of

I thought this was a good lecture series for our first year at YSPH to introduce a lot of topics that will be useful and necessary as we go forward in our public health careers. Not a lot of the material was new, but it was good to make sure everyone was on the same page.
Strength: no work outside class, and informative
Seriously, we have to review this course?? I thought this was a pointless annoying waste of a few hours invented for purely beaurocratic purposes.
good overview of ethics and proper research conduct
The seminar was helpful but I have also gone through the material many times previously.
GREAT speakers this semester.

This two-day seminar on ethics was a waste of time. There seemed to be a lack of seriousness from the beginning of the lecture. It felt like we were essentially just fulfilling a requirement. I thought it was disappointing that this opportunity was not used to stress the importance of ethics. There is such a cavalier attitude among students and academics that their work is ethical and that they would never do anything that would be "unethical." Perhaps my perspective is biased since I have taken classes in bioethics, however I felt like this seminar was not taken seriously.

The instructor was excellent given the very boring, but necessary, subject matter. The structure of the course only meeting a couple of time at the beginning of the semester seemed to work for everyone.
Dr. Bruce did a great job of making the required lecture series both informative and entertaining.
Poorly delivered...just another checked-box
very interesting!
Its a great introduction to research ethics. However, i think the second night was repetitive and unnecessary.
entertaining and interesting
The course was taught in seminar format. Perhaps we can break down into smaller groups to discuss ethical issues? I feel that would give the students more chance to participate.
Good
Didn't learn anything about ethics. This "course" was a joke.
This was a poorly run course. Disorganized, professor sped through the material at a pace that student was unable to keep up any of the material.
N/A
The course did not teach about research ethics. Rather, it was a two day seminar on what the instructor believed to be ethical and unethical.

The guy did a nice job getting through the material while being as engaging as possible. It might be nice to offer the course twice, in different timeslots (Sat morning, maybe?) I had to miss a weekly seminar that only met twice to go to this workshop.
It was an interesting approach to research ethics.It could have been more interactive- perhaps with small group discussion.
fine
very well done.
This course seemed to me to be just a check box for the School of Public health, to show that all students have some ethics courses. I don't beleive anyone can learn anything from such a course.
The course was good- it raised questions about ethical issues and provided me with insight on how to go about dealing with those issues.
good

This really was the same-old set of material we get in other bio-ethics courses. I'm just really thankful that it was only two lectures in length, but it really could be shortened down to just a single lecture.
GREAT!

This course should be a full semester class, not an awkwardly long lecture in the middle of dinner. I liked the topics covered, and think we *should* be learning about bioethics, but this isn't the best way to do it. Make it a requirement for a full semester, and cut a semester of epi.
All right, required course that had to be taken.
The two sessions were interesting, but I got the feeling that if we are really interested, it is up to us to pursue further information.

This short course is on a very important topic, yet there is only 2 short periods worth dedicated for it. You cannot expect for anyone to walk away from such short durations of time and actually learn anything meaningful.If one MUST limit this subject to such a short period of time, then I would stick with the idea of getting an outside speaker who specializes in public health ethics. Outside speakers tend to be more enthusiastic speakers and refreshing for the audience. While this is my recommendation, my review of the instructor for this course (below) reveals that it is not necessarily the recipe for success.
I think some sort of evaluation post-completion would be useful to incentivize better participation from the student body.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Overall good instructor. Tried to make dry subject matter interesting.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  awesome instructor, very funny and approaches the issue in a comical yet serious way that made me listen during the seminar
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Very entertaining. Engaged the students. Good job.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  energetic, engaging,
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He did a good job of making us understand the important concepts without dragging the class on for too long.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr. Bruce was hilarious and charismatic. He should teach more classes at YSPH.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He's very engaging
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Great sense of humor!

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Professor Bruce was great at leading these sections - he really tried to keep people engaged and relate the material to our lives in a meaningful way. He was good at holding the attention of everyone in the auditorium while still conveying the necessary material.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Highly entertaining.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Very interesting and informative.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  great instructor. very interactive with the audience.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He was a good presenter. He encouraged participation from the students and answered our questions.

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Although the instructor tried to use humor, I thought it came across as indifference. I don't think his type of humor and casual attitude is appropriate in this context. I think ethics is a serious topic.

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  The instructor made inappropriate jokes about women, republicans, and religion. this is an ethics course after all. he should have exercised better judgement. i was very offended and almost walked out of the room. he has very biting humor that crossed the line, and i'm not the only person who felt offended.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  The instructor is extremely personable and related to the students well. I thiought some of the examples he gave were relevant. Also, his slides were well-done.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr. Bruce did a great job!
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Great instructor! Keeps the instruction light and makes it fun. Entertaining!
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Poor--disrespectful in his attempts at humor.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Great instructor; would recommend for him to instruct again
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Great!

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He approached somewhat boring subject with his own humor and wit, and consequently, it made the course much more interesting. He also effectively promoted students' participation during the course, which I liked.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He was funny. It made a boring subject bearable with his humor.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Disrespectful, made inappropriate comments, appeared to care less about the course and appeared to rush through the material for his own benefit.

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Extremely unprofessional! At the end of the seminar, I understood Dr. Bruce's standing on ethics, but did not gain an understanding of the larger picture of the topic. Rather, Dr. Bruce spent two sessions giving students his opinion about black women on welfare, republicans and Texans. He did more to offend than teach, and I recommend that he keep his opinions to himself next year.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  The guy did a nice job getting through the material while being as engaging as possible.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr. Bruce provides good information, however in an attempt to energize his audience he tends to become slightly combative in his questioning.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr. Bruce was very engaging and intelligent.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  good
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  interesting professor with a great delivery of ethics in research. Glad we had the seminar!
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He's great!
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr. Bruce was a great instructor- he gave insightful examples for me to think of how ethical dilemmas could actually play out in the real world.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  amazing
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He knew his material, but I felt condescended to, and was bored by his lecture style.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  He tried to spruce up the course that he knew was required but it is a pretty dry subject.
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Entertaining
Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  Dr Bruce is very entertaining and takes ethics seriously. I thought he was the perfect person to present these two sessions.

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  The instructor clearly was trying very hard to cater to the crowd, but in the end tried too hard and crossed too many lines (e.g. risky joking led to offensive jokes). While I appreciate his eagerness to please, his personality ended up being more memorable than the course material, and not in a positive manner.

Instructor: Robert Douglas Bruce  While I appreciated the humor of the instructor and his desire to keep us engaged, I do think it detracted from the importance of the training. It might be better to try a different method of keeping the audience engaged.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: seminar on ethics. 4 hours total. Just sit, listen and try to learn something. Information is relevant, just dry.
Ethics is very important, and everyone has to take the seminar regardless
Required, but necessary. Well done.
2 day seminar about bioethics. Very interesting stories. I like the seminar format
The course gives a brief introduction to research ethics and presents some of the boundaries that relate to field work and research in general.
You have to take it, but it's really not that bad. Dr. Bruce is an awesome speaker.
Dr. Bruce does a nice job in this role and led a thought provoking discussion
A primer on research ethics - gives a sense of what people can expect for their internships, theses
Yes, requested by YSPH
great seminar
Waste of time....
This Ethics seminar is mandatory and explains topics and requirement surrounding ethics for those not already familiar with the material.
This semester was leaps-and-bounds more interesting than last. I enjoyed each and every lecture.
If this was an optional seminar, I would not recommend it.

Because it is so short and covers such important material, I would recommend it to another student. It is a good introduction to ethics in health careers and provides resources for those who are more involved in ethical issues than others.
interesting and informative
Mandatory course
Necessary
It was great, and the time slots worked out well.
Interesting
Required so go.
Needs to be restructured

As a required seminar, I appreciated Dr Bruce keeping the mood light and providing interesting examples. However, since we do have to be there, we might as well learn something. Some content regarding ethics would have been nice. Also, I believe students need that, even a simple overview. We can' take for granted that each of us truly knows what is ethical, what is not, and how to assess a given situation.
This class provides an overview of research ethics in public health.
annoying
Discussion of ethical issues in public health research
Does what it has to do.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students- it is important to just know how ethics can play out in the profession of public health.
practical and useful
Yes, it is required, but it was very interesting and important for any research endeavors.
A pretty good illustration of the little emphasis that YSPH places on anything that cannot be quantitatively measured.
This was a two day seminar on the guidelines of ethical public health research. I would recommend training in this area, but not necessarily this course if there is an option.
